intro: Dipcadi sansibaricum, commonly known as the East African buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of East Africa. It belongs to the family Melanthiaceae and is characterized by its showy, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has a short, rhizomatous stem and produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. Its leaves are typically narrow and grass-like, growing in dense clusters near the ground. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal dunes and sandy habitats.
